caseTitle: SAMUEL ADOM BOTCHWAY v. SAMUEL ADDO OSEI
summary: In Samuel Adom Botchway v. Samuel Addo Osei (CA No. 261/87, 6 February 2003), the Court of Appeal of Ghana upheld the High Court’s decision nullifying a conveyance of land from the plaintiff to the defendant. The plaintiff claimed he never sold the land and that the conveyance (Exhibit 'B') was forged. The defendant claimed he purchased the land from one Kwesi Tetteh, who appeared only as a witness on the document, and relied on a police report affirming the plaintiff’s signature. The Court found the document inherently fraudulent due to internal inconsistencies, including the improper role of Kwesi Tetteh, and held that the defendant failed to conduct due diligence by not searching the land title. The principle of nemo dat quod non habet applied, as Kwesi Tetteh had no title to convey. The defendant’s counterclaim for refund of ₵50,000 was rejected; the court found the payment unrelated to a land sale, noting the lack of a receipt and contradictory conduct. The appeal was dismissed, affirming the plaintiff’s ownership and possession of the land.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; High Court judgment upheld nullifying the conveyance and rejecting the defendant's counterclaim.
citations: SAMUEL ADOM BOTCHWAY v. SAMUEL ADDO OSEI [6/2/2003] CA NO. 261/87
C.I.19 (The Court of Appeal Rules, 1997 as amended)
rationaleHighlights: The entire conveyance document (Exhibit 'B') was deemed spurious despite a police report suggesting the signature was genuine, due to inconsistencies in names and roles.
The defendant failed to conduct a land search or verify title, disqualifying him from protection as a bona fide purchaser for value without notice.
The principle of nemo dat quod non habet applied because Kwesi Tetteh, as mere witness, had no title to transfer.
The payment of ₵50,000 was not for land purchase, as no receipt was issued and the defendant’s counterclaim for refund contradicted a purchase agreement.
The trial court’s judgment was upheld as reasonable based on documentary and testimonial inconsistencies.
